metadata.title: GitLeaks to NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5 Mapping

methodology.description: Rules are classified by secret type using keyword patterns, then mapped to CWE weaknesses, which are mapped to NIST controls.

metadata.academic_statement: Secret type taxonomy is researcher-derived from GitLeaks rule naming conventions. CWE assignments follow MITRE definitions. NIST mappings are based on official control statements. Unclassified rules default to CWE-798 as all GitLeaks rules detect credential exposure per OWASP ASVS V2.10.4.

CWE-798.name: Use of Hard-coded Credentials
CWE-798.nist_rationale: Hard-coded credentials violate IA-5 (Authenticator Management) which requires "Establishing initial authenticator content" and "Ensuring authenticators have sufficient strength of mechanism" (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5, IA-5).

CWE-321.name: Use of Hard-coded Cryptographic Key
CWE-321.nist_rationale: Hard-coded cryptographic keys violate SC-12 (Cryptographic Key Establishment and Management) which requires managing keys per "organization-defined requirements for key generation, distribution, storage, access, and destruction" (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5, SC-12).

CWE-256.name: Plaintext Storage of a Password
CWE-256.nist_rationale: Plaintext password storage violates IA-5(1) (Password-Based Authentication) which requires "Store passwords using an approved salted key derivation function" (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5, IA-5(1)d).

CWE-522.name: Insufficiently Protected Credentials
CWE-522.nist_rationale: Insufficiently protected credentials (tokens, cookies) violate IA-5 which requires "Ensuring authenticators have sufficient strength of mechanism for their intended use" (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5, IA-5c).

CWE-200.name: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor
CWE-200.nist_rationale: Exposure of sensitive configuration (client IDs, webhook URLs) indicates configuration management failure per CM-6 which requires "configuration settings that reflect the most restrictive mode" (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5, CM-6a).

classification_patterns.rationale: Pattern "private-key" indicates asymmetric cryptographic private key
PKCS#12 files contain bundled private keys and certificates
Age is a file encryption tool; its keys are cryptographic
OAuth client secrets are authentication credentials
Client IDs are identifiers with lower sensitivity than secrets
Access tokens are bearer credentials for authentication
Refresh tokens require protection per OWASP ASVS V3.5
Session cookies are insufficiently protected if exposed
API keys are hard-coded credentials per OWASP ASVS V2.10.4
API tokens function as authentication credentials
Access keys (e.g., AWS) are authentication credentials
Plaintext password storage per CWE-256 definition
Rules ending in "-token" indicate authentication tokens
Rules ending in "-secret" indicate secret credentials
Rules ending in "-key" typically indicate API/access keys
